text.author: MTSAMPLES.COM
text.title: Anemia & Leukemia Followup
text.summary1: (human1) After examining a 72 year old man (allergic to Vicodin) with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) since May 2008 and currently taking 5mg predinsone every other day, a physician reports he is suffering from autoimmune hemolytic anemia and oral ulcers on the lip and tongue, and puts him back on Valtrex and lowers steroids to 1mg daily ahead of a clinic visit the next week.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) 72-year-old male with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (diagnosed May 2008) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia on chronic steroids presents for follow-up with stable blood counts, oral ulcers after discontinuing antivirals, and plan to restart Valtrex and adjust steroid dosage.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) A 72-year-old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, on prednisone and other medications, presented with oral ulcers and visual issues, requiring follow-up and alteration of his steroid regimen, resumption of antiviral therapy, and a plan to review his condition in a week.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) A 72-year-old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia reports an oral ulcer, night vision issues, and headaches, with stable blood counts on chronic steroids.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-3B-Instruct) A 72-year-old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia discusses his ongoing treatment, including current medications and a plan to increase Valtrex use and decrease corticosteroid dosage.
